item.title: Turkey Detains Building Contractors as Recovery Efforts Ramp Up
item.description: As the death toll in Turkey and Syria passed 28,000, Ankara was coming under growing criticism for its slow response and tolerance of shoddy construction.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad, Raja Abdulrahim, Safak Timur, Steven Erlanger and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times

item.title: Wagner Founder Has Putin’s Support, but the Kremlin’s Side-Eye
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the once secretive tycoon, is confounding Moscow’s Kremlin-allied elite by starting to dabble in politics alongside waging war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Artem Krasnov/Kommersant, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, right, the founder of the Wagner private military company, in September at a memorial service for a Wagner soldier in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: Corruption Trial of Mexican Ex-Lawman Ripples Beyond Courtroom
item.description: As prosecutors close their case against Genaro García Luna, the eventual verdict will be felt by Mexican officials and among U.S. agents who work there.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Tomas Bravo/Reuters
item.media:description: Genaro Garciá Luna, who once served as the public face of Mexico’s war on drugs, is accused of taking millions in bribes from the very cartels he was supposed to be pursuing.

item.title: AKA, Influential South African Rapper, Is Fatally Shot
item.description: The rapper, whose legal name was Kiernan Forbes, was one of the most formidable songwriters in South African hip-hop. He and another man were killed outside a restaurant on Friday.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Rajesh Jantilal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kiernan Forbes, the rapper popularly known as AKA, performing in 2016 at the South African Music Awards in Durban.

item.title: Anger Over Turkey’s Earthquake Response Challenges Erdogan Ahead of Election
item.description: A furor is building among some survivors over the government’s handling of the crisis. “I have been voting for this government for 20 years,” said one. “I will never forgive them.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Erdogan assessed the earthquake damage in Kahramanmaras on Wednesday.

item.title: Repeat Election in Berlin Speaks to the ‘Chaos’ Many Residents Feel
item.description: The do-over vote on Sunday is only the tip of the iceberg for a city some see as in crisis: short on housing, schools and efficient governance.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evening rush hour in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Rushes to Repair After Wave of Russian Strikes
item.description: Russia hit several regions with Iranian-made drones overnight, capping a day in which its forces unleashed a major barrage of missiles on critical sites around Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A darkened street in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday. Russia has repeatedly attacked the country’s power grid.

item.title: Life as the Mayor of Kherson: No Sleep. Lots of Shelling. And Some Cognac.
item.description: Being the leader of Kherson may feel more like a curse than an honor. But one woman isn’t giving up, even though the Russians are sitting just across the river and shelling her city nearly every hour.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Halyna Luhova, the mayor of Kherson, spoke on her phone on her way to a meeting with local volunteers in Kherson.

item.title: Toronto Mayor John Tory Resigns, Admitting to Relationship With Employee
item.description: The mayor, John Tory, who had led the city since 2014, apologized for what he called a serious error in judgment.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Arlyn Mcadorey/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: John Tory, mayor of Toronto, announced on Friday night he was stepping down, after acknowledging he’d had an extramarital relationship with a staffer.

item.title: At Least 2 Dead as Driver Rams Bus Stop in East Jerusalem
item.description: A man drove a car into a group of civilians outside an Israeli settlement in what the police described as a terrorist attack. A 6-year-old was among those killed.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene where a driver hit a group of people in East Jerusalem on Friday. It was the latest incident in a surge of violence involving Palestinians and Israelis.

item.title: What We Know About the Earthquake in Turkey and Syria
item.description: As the death toll rises in the one of the deadliest quakes in decades, a global humanitarian aid effort faces deep challenges.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians and residents crushing the rubble as they try to retrieve the bodies trapped inside a collapsed building in Iskenderun, Turkey, after the earthquake.

item.title: E.U. Lawmaker Arrested in Qatar-Linked Corruption Inquiry
item.description: The detention of Marc Tarabella, who lost his immunity last week, is part of a long-running investigation into whether there were efforts to influence the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Kenzo Tribouillard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Marc Tarabella of Belgium is accused of supporting “certain positions within the European Parliament in favor of a third state” in exchange for up to 140,000 euros.

item.title: China, Still Trying to Play Down Balloon, Finds It’s Getting Harder to Do
item.description: Beijing has accused the United States of waging “information and public opinion warfare.” But analysts say a lack of credible messaging from China is not helping.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy
item.media:credit: F.B.I., via Associated Press
item.media:description: An F.B.I. team processing remnants from the Chinese balloon at a laboratory in Quantico, Va., on Thursday.

item.title: Solomon Perel, Jew Who Posed as a Hitler Youth to Survive, Dies at 97
item.description: His masquerade — a tale recounted in a memoir and in the film “Europa Europa” — saved his life. But “to this day,” he said, “I have a tangle of two souls in one body.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Sueddeutsche Zeitung Photo/Alamy
item.media:description: Solomon Perel in an undated photo. “I’m not a Jew,” he lied to his Wehrmacht captors in 1941. “I’m an ethnic German.”

item.title: Hazel McCallion, No-Nonsense Canadian Mayor for 36 Years, Dies at 101
item.description: Tough, pragmatic and brusque when she had to be, she helped transform Mississauga from a sleepy Toronto suburb into one of the country’s largest and most dynamic cities.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Cole Burston/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hazel McCallion posed with a cardboard cutout of herself last May at an exhibition in Mississauga, Ontario, focused on her long life in public service.

item.title: Master Hsing Yun, Monk Who Spread Buddhism in China, Dies at 95
item.description: He established a modern brand of Buddhism in Taiwan and opened temples around the world, becoming the rare religious figure backed by Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Massimo Sambucetti/Associated Press
item.media:description: Master Hsing Yun, center, and members of his delegation visiting the Vatican in 1997. His movement flourished in China because it focused on individual piety and compassion, not social change, and did not challenge the government.

item.title: Valentine’s Day
item.description: In honor of the holiday, let’s look at the language of love.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Can Money Buy Love? Romance Scammers Want You to Believe It.
item.description: As fraudsters sharpen their hustles, the money lost to romance scams has more than doubled during the pandemic, costing Canadians millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nam Y. Huh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Valentine’s Day is approaching, and scams are in the air.

item.title: Russia Attacks Ukraine With Major Missile Barrage as Combat Intensifies
item.description: The first major aerial bombardment in weeks targeted cities across Ukraine, as President Volodymyr Zelensky returned home from a trip across Europe to press for more arms.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Hayko, 35, and her 4-year-old son Vladislav take shelter during an air raid alarm in a subway station in Kyiv, on Friday.

item.title: Volunteers in Turkey Construct Makeshift Hospitals in Earthquake Zone
item.description: In place of damaged or destroyed hospitals, a series of field clinics have sprung up in Turkey, with doctors and nurses from around the world.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Medical personnel, many of them volunteers, rush a quake victim to a field hospital in Antakya, Turkey, on Friday.

item.title: Where Even the Food Is Magic: A Treasure Hunt for the Flavors of Caribbean Colombia
item.description: In a region Gabriel García Márquez once called home, a garlic-and-coconut-infused journey guided by the culinary expertise of another local celebrity, the acclaimed chef Leonor Espinosa.
item.dc:creator: Abbie Kozolchyk
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shrimp ceviche with plantains at El Canto de la Caracola, a restaurant in Rincón del Mar, Colombia, a former fishing village where fresh seafood still figures prominently on local menus.

item.title: Biden Plans to Visit Poland for One-year Anniversary of Ukraine War
item.description: The president will be in the region for three days, but the White House did not say if he would make a trip into Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Brazil Says it Won’t Send Weapons to Ukraine Despite Push from U.S.
item.description: The Brazilian leader, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who met with President Biden at the White House, said he’s interested in helping negotiate a path to peace.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil and President Biden at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Pentagon Shoots Down Unidentified Object At High Altitude Over Alaska
item.description: The incident comes less than a week after a U.S. fighter jet brought down a Chinese spy balloon over the Atlantic during a diplomatic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Kirby, a White House spokesman, confirmed on Friday that the Pentagon shot down an object over Alaska.

item.title: What Statistics Can’t Capture About the Global Baby Bust
item.description: Falling fertility has been hard to reverse, despite so many governments’ best efforts, because it’s not one thing, it’s everything.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children and parents at a playground in Xiapu, China. China’s population is now officially shrinking.

item.title: Amsterdam Bans Marijuana Smoking on Streets of Red-Light District
item.description: The new regulations, which will take effect in mid-May, were introduced in response to complaints from residents about disruptive tourists.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The red-light district in Amsterdam. New regulations that come into effect in May will target crowding, disruptive behavior and noise in its most famous district.

item.title: Biden and Lula Meet at White House, Vowing to Guard Democracy
item.description: President Biden hosted Brazil’s new president on Friday in a refresh of the countries’ relations. The two leaders agree on the Amazon but are split on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: The meeting between the two leaders, just 40 days into Mr. Lula’s presidency, was framed as a renewal of the relationship between the two largest countries in the Western Hemisphere.

item.title: Ronald S. Lauder Reaches Agreement on Klimt Painting With Jewish Heirs
item.description: Mr. Lauder agreed to the restitution and repurchase of the painting from the relatives of an art collector who fled Europe in 1943 to avoid Nazi persecution.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan

item.title: Putin Used Secret Decree to Pardon Ex-Inmate Who Joined Ukraine War Effort, Document Shows
item.description: A copy of a prison release certificate reviewed by The New York Times offers evidence of what activists say is a mass pardon campaign to entice tens of thousands of inmates to enter battle.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ekaterina Bodyagina

item.title: Natalia Gavrilita, Prime Minister of Moldova, Resigns
item.description: Natalia Gavrilita had been prime minister since 2021, when she took charge of the government after elections gave a strong majority in Parliament to pro-Western politicians.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Aurel Obreja/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Natalia Gavrilita of Moldova announces her resignation during a news conference on Friday in Chisinau, Moldova.

item.title: Did He Say ‘Bird?’
item.description: We talk with Sam Altman, the C.E.O. of OpenAI, about the artificial-intelligence craze.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Altman.

item.title: Romania Says Russian Missile Did Not Enter Its Airspace
item.description: Ukrainian officials said that two Russian missiles crossed into the airspace of Moldova and Romania before entering Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Monika Pronczuk

item.title: The Australians in the Super Bowl
item.description: How Jordan Mailata and Arryn Siposs made it to the N.F.L.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Chris Szagola/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jordan Mailata, left, and Arryn Siposs of the Philadelphia Eagles during an N.F.L. game in November.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A Turkish city lost in the earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man watched volunteers search for bodies in the old quarter of Antakya City in Hatay Province on Thursday.

item.title: Turkey-Syria Earthquake Death Toll Tops 23,000 Amid Struggle for Aid
item.description: Only a trickle of humanitarian aid has reached the devastated parts of Syria because years of war have carved the country into zones of control that impede deliveries.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Hwaida Saad and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying a body found by rescuers in a collapsed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on Thursday. This has now become Turkey’s deadliest earthquake since 1939.

item.title: With So Many Dead in Turkey, Families Forced to Rush Funeral Rites
item.description: The earthquake that hit in southern Turkey has killed more than 17,500 people there, overwhelming the traditional funeral process and accelerating how families say goodbye.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: People burying their relatives in a cemetery near Kapicam, Turkey.

item.title: ‘This Is Our Fate’: A Syrian Family Is Displaced in Southern Turkey
item.description: Syrian refugees displaced by the earthquake in southern Turkey say they need water and more tents to keep their children warm.
item.dc:creator: Tolga Ildun and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:credit: Tolga Ildun for The New York Times

item.title: In Speech to E.U. Leaders, Zelensky Links Europe to Ukraine’s Fate
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky, in only his second trip outside Ukraine since the conflict began, told European lawmakers that his country’s war against Russia was a defense of all Europe.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Omar Havana/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking at the European Parliament in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Turkey Says Earthquake Wiped Out City of Antakya
item.description: Amid scenes of utter devastation and widespread suffering in the bitter cold, residents mourned the loss of family, friends and memories.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man watched as volunteers searched for bodies in the old quarter of Antakya in Hatay Province in Turkey on Thursday.

item.title: As Aid Trickles Into Syria, Residents Say Too Little, Too Late
item.description: “Some people under ruins are sharing their wills with the team,” said one rescue worker. “They share names of their loved ones, then they die.”
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Hwaida Saad and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Praying over the bodies of earthquake victims in Syria on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: 20,000 Dead in Turkey and Syria
item.description: Also, new U.S. information about China’s spy balloon and North Korea’s newest missile.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ghaith Alsayed/Associated Press
item.media:description: The quake’s aftermath in the Syrian town of Jinderis in Aleppo province.

item.title: Roger Waters of Pink Floyd Weighs In on Russia-Ukraine War, Again
item.description: An address at the United Nations this week is dismissed by an American ambassador.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images
item.media:description: Roger Waters in Los Angeles in September.

item.title: Earthquake in Turkey and Syria Is One of the Deadliest in Decades
item.description: The death toll surpassed 20,000 on Thursday, a grim milestone that makes it among the deadliest since 2000.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman walking through Port-au-Prince in 2010 after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake hit Haiti, killing over 200,000 people.

item.title: In Turkey, a Parking Lot Becomes an Open-Air Morgue After Earthquake
item.description: Hundreds of families searched for deceased relatives at a makeshift morgue outside a hospital in Turkey’s hardest-hit region.
item.dc:creator: Tolga Ildun, Yousur Al-Hlou and Mark Boyer
item.media:credit: Tolga Ildun for The New York Times

item.title: South African President Declares ‘State of Disaster’ Over Power Crisis
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa, facing rising public wrath, on Thursday declared a “state of disaster” and pledged to end an energy crisis that threatens economic and political stability.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Ilan Godfrey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bank ATMs providing light from solar power in an otherwise dark city center because of power cuts in Meyerton, South Africa, on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Not Just a Silly Balloon’: Dismay and Fear Over Another U.S.-China Clash
item.description: A big white orb has pushed the rival superpowers back to diplomatic distance, showing that peace may be frighteningly fragile.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Chase Doak, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Chinese balloon soaring over Billings, Mont., last week.

item.title: Church of England Considers Gender-Neutral Language for God
item.description: The church said that God was neither male nor female and has asked a commission to explore how that is reflected in its services.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Church of England’s governing body, the General Synod, met in London this week and discussed topics including gender-neutral language for God and same-sex marriage.

item.title: Elon Musk Won’t Let His Starlink Satellites Run Ukraine’s Drones
item.description: The comments angered some leaders in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier disconnects a Starlink satellite dish near Kreminna, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Russia’s Wagner Mercenary Group Says It Has Stopped Recruiting Prisoners
item.description: Thousands of released convicts have been killed, many soon after arriving on the battlefield in Ukraine, Russian rights advocates and Ukrainian officials say.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Graves of Wagner fighters at a cemetery near the village of Bakinskaya in Russia.

item.title: Nicaragua Frees Hundreds of Political Prisoners to the U.S.
item.description: The authoritarian government of Daniel Ortega handed over 222 prisoners as a way to signal a desire to restart relations with the United States, according to officials.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Inti Ocon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers outside the house of the opposition presidential candidate Cristiana Chamorro Barrios in 2021, after she was arrested. Ms. Chamorro was among those released on Thursday and who are flying to Washington.

item.title: Chinese Balloon Had Tools to Collect Electronic Communications, U.S. Says
item.description: China’s surveillance balloons have flown over more than 40 countries and are directed by the Chinese military, the State Department said. The F.B.I. is studying debris.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: MCS1 Tyler Thompson/U.S. Navy
item.media:description: This picture provided by the U.S. Navy shows sailors recovering a Chinese high-altitude surveillance balloon off the coast of South Carolina.

item.title: First Significant Aid Arrives in Northwestern Syria After Quake
item.description: The U.N. convoy was carrying shelter material and non-food items to the opposition-held region.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A United Nations aid convoy of six trucks that entered the opposition-held northwestern Syria from Turkey through the Bab al-Hawa crossing on Thursday.

item.title: Biden’s Fight Against ‘Junk Fees’
item.description: Why the Biden administration is trying to crack down on those sneaky fees charged by hotels, rental cars, internet providers and more.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Paul Sakuma/Associated Press

item.title: What China’s Military Balloons Show About Its Spying Ambitions
item.description: Chinese military scientists have been looking for ways to make them more durable, harder to detect and even to serve as platforms that fire advanced weapons.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Chad Fish, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Chinese spy balloon that floated over the United States seemed a new phenomenon. But China has long tested and used balloons as surveillance craft.

item.title: Life on the Beat for Ukraine’s Cops: The Drunk, the Disorderly and Drones
item.description: In cities dealing with bombardment and blackouts, the Patrol Police have taken a lead in trying to retain a sense of security for a traumatized public.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officer Svitlana Lukianenkova, 30, and her Patrol Police colleague Officer Stanislav Skrypnyk, 28, at work in Kyiv, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: Freed Guantánamo Prisoner Has Big Dreams for a New Life in Belize
item.description: Majid Khan, a “high-value detainee” at Guantánamo Bay, was released last week after two decades of social isolation.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times

item.title: Can China Reverse Its Population Decline? Just Ask Sweden.
item.description: Wealthy countries have been trying to boost their birthrates for decades. The results have been pretty similar.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs and Francesca Paris

item.title: U.S. Aims to Curb Investment in China Amid Security Concerns
item.description: The Biden administration is preparing new rules that would restrict U.S. dollars from flowing to China.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Zhong Min/Feature China, via Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The measures are expected to prohibit investments in certain areas deemed risky for national security.

item.title: Kizzmekia Corbett Unlocked the Science of the Covid Vaccine
item.description: Kizzmekia Corbett helped lead a team of scientists contributing to one of the most stunning achievements in the history of immunizations: a highly effective, easily manufactured vaccine against Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kizzmekia Corbett was at the vanguard of the race for a vaccine against Covid-19. Above, she is in her office at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health in Boston.
